case_name: Ratepayers of Municipal Committee of Shegaon v. Municipal Committee of Shegaon and State of Bombay

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 234 of 1959 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 234 of 1959. Appeal from the order dated February 15, 1957 of the Bombay High Court of Judicature at Nagpur in Special Civil Application No. 2-N of 1956.

facts.text: Appeal is from the order dated February 15, 1957 of the Bombay High Court at Nagpur in Special Civil Application No. 2-N of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the order dated February 15, 1957 of the Bombay High Court of Judicature at Nagpur in Special Civil Application No. 2-N of 1956. P. Varma, for appellant No. 1. S. Shastri and Ganpat Rai, for respondent No. 1.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 28, 1961 by KAPUR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. March 28. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.-This is an appeal on a certificate by the High Court of Bombay against the judgment and order of that Court passed on a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution

facts.text: Appellants are ratepayers of the Municipal Committee of Shegaon, respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are some of the ratepayers of the Municipal Committee of Shegaon which is respondent No. I in this appeal. The other respondent is the State of Bombay.

facts.text: Appellants carry on trade and business involving bringing goods within limits of Municipal Committee.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants were carrying on trade and business which involved their bringing goods within the limits of the Municipal Committee.

facts.text: Municipal Committee passed resolution on July 25, 1954 for levying octroi duty instead of terminal tax.

anchor.surface_text: On July 25,1954, the Municipal Committee passed a resolution for tile purpose of levying an octroi duty instead of terminal tax.

facts.text: Resolution published in State Gazette on June 29, 1956 along with rules for assessment.

anchor.surface_text: This resolution was published in the State Gazette on June 29, 1956, along with rules for assessment.

facts.text: Objections to proposed tax invited on August 4, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Oil August 4, 1956, objections were invited to the proposed tax.

facts.text: First appellant filed objections on August 4, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The objections by the first appellant were filed on August 4, 1956, and by some others on August 5 and 6.

facts.text: Other appellants filed objections on August 5 and 6, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: and by some others on August 5 and 6. At a meeting of the Municipal Committee dated August 16, 1956, the objections of the other appellants were rejected as being time barred

facts.text: At meeting on August 16, 1956, Municipal Committee rejected objections of other appellants as time barred.

anchor.surface_text: At a meeting of the Municipal Committee dated August 16, 1956, the objections of the other appellants were rejected as being time barred and those by the first appellant were rejected

facts.text: Municipal Committee rejected first appellant's objections because it was the only objector within time.

anchor.surface_text: the objections of the other appellants were rejected as being time barred and those by the first appellant were rejected because it was the only objector whose objections were within time.

facts.text: First appellant made representations to the Government.

anchor.surface_text: Some representations were made by the first appellant to the Government and a few days later the other objectors also made similar representations

facts.text: Government issued notification sanctioning imposition of tax and draft rules on October 27, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: but the Government issued the numberification sanctioning the imposition of the tax and the Draft Rules on October 27, 1956, though the Gazette Notifications were published

facts.text: Gazette notifications published on October 30 and October 31, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: though the Gazette Notifications were published on two separate dates, i.e., October 30 and October 31, 1956.

facts.text: Appellants filed petition under Art. 226 in Bombay High Court at Nagpur challenging legality of tax imposition.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants then filed a petition under Art. 226 in the High Court of Bombay at Nagpur challenging the legality of the, imposition of the tax.

facts.text: Petition urged two grounds: 1. notification ultra vires as s.67 not complied with; 2. rate of tax exceeded maximum.

anchor.surface_text: Two main grounds were urged-  1  that the numberification was ultra vires because s. 67 of the C. P. Berar Municipalities Act, 1922  Act II of 1922 , hereinafter termed the Act, had number been companyplied with and  2  that the rate

facts.text: High Court rejected first ground but accepted second and gave relief.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected the first ground but accepted the second objection and gave relief accordingly.

facts.text: Appellants Nos. 2 to 6 have not taken steps for prosecution of appeal; appeal dismissed as to them for non-prosecution.

anchor.surface_text: Appellants Nos. 2 to 6 have number taken steps for the prosecution of the appeal and the appeal, in so far as it relates to them, is dismissed for number-prosecution.

facts.text: Appellant No. 1 challenges vires on grounds: 1. not all steps under s.67 taken; 2. no notification imposing octroi duty.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant No. 1 before us has challenged the vires of the imposition on two grounds  1  that all the steps necessary for the imposition of the octroi duty had number been taken and therefore s. 67 had number

facts.text: High Court found that objections of appellant No.1 not considered on merits, which was error in procedure.

anchor.surface_text: although it found that number-consideration of the objections was an error in procedure. The language of sub- s.  8  lends support to this view.

facts.text: Two notifications issued by Government on October 27, 1956; one published Oct 30, other Oct 31.

anchor.surface_text: As stated above, there were two numberifications issued by the Government both of October 27, 1956. One was published in the Gazette on October 30, 1956, and the other on the following day.

facts.text: Second notification confirms draft rules for imposition of octroi tax under s.67(2), but court finds it should be under s.67(7).

anchor.surface_text: The second numberification on the face of it is under sub-s.  2  of s. 67. It appears to us that this is a mistake and should have been under sub-a.  7  of s. 67.

facts.text: Notification is conclusive evidence that tax imposed in accordance with Act per s.67(8).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected this plea because of s. 67 8 , although it found that number-consideration of the objections was an error in procedure.

facts.text: Court holds second notification directs imposition of octroi and is conclusive evidence.

anchor.surface_text: This numberification therefore clearly is one which directs imposition of octroi and falls within sub- s.  7  of s. 67 and having been numberified in the Gazette it is companyclusive evidence of the tax having been imposed
petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution by the present appellants in regard to the legality of the notification levying an octroi duty on certain goods.
The appellants then filed a petition under Art. 226 in the High Court of Bombay at Nagpur challenging the legality of the, imposition of the tax.
that the notification was ultra vires because s. 67 of the C. P. Berar Municipalities Act, 1922 (Act II of 1922), hereinafter termed the Act, had not been complied with

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.67(8) makes the notification conclusive evidence of compliance with the Act notwithstanding procedural errors such as non-consideration of objections on merits

holdings.text: This, in our opinion, is not established that there was no notification imposing the tax

holdings.reasoning_summary: Two notifications were issued by the Government on October 27, 1956, published in Gazette

holdings.text: The second notification on the face of it is under sub-s. (2) of s. 67 but this is a mistake and should have been under sub-s. (7) of s. 67

anchor.surface_text: The second numberification on the face of it is under sub-s. (2) of s. 67. It appears to us that this is a mistake and should have been under sub-s. (7) of s. 67.

holdings.reasoning_summary: The content of the notification confirms draft rules for imposition of octroi tax, which aligns with powers under sub-s.(7) rather than sub-s.(2)

holdings.text: This notification therefore clearly is one which directs imposition of octroi and falls within sub-s. (7) of s. 67 and having been notified in the Gazette it is conclusive evidence of the tax having been imposed in accordance with the provisions of the Act and it cannot be challenged on the ground that all the necessary steps had not been taken

anchor.surface_text: This numberification therefore clearly is one which directs imposition of octroi and falls within sub- s.  7  of s. 67 and having been numberified in the Gazette it is companyclusive evidence of the tax having been imposed in accordance with the provisions of the Act and it cannot be challenged on the ground that all the necessary steps had number been taken.

holdings.reasoning_summary: The notification's content directs imposition by confirming rules at specified rates on specified goods, invokes s.67(7) and s.67(8) conclusive evidence clause
